Percival Fawcett.Action: Strikes us as cheerful. A gentle voice, an even manner.
Eyes reveal capacity for furious wrath and implacable resolution, held in leash.
Emerges from the fog described as primal, mythic, elemental; described as resolved, committed, with a capacity for furious wrath and implacable resolution held in leash.
Embraces his wife and newborn son, appearing ecstatic and glowing during the christening.
Greets attendees politely and expresses gratitude for their attendance.
Shows gentle affection by caressing his infant son's hand during the christening.
Sets the men to rights after they made a complete hash of drill.
Arrives late to the christening, seemingly after managing difficulties with men’s drill.
Touches the mandala necklace with reverence during the child's ceremony.
Smiles and becomes emotional during the baptism ceremony.
Expresses commitment to raising his son himself so the children are not strangers to their parents.
Expresses intention to raise children as dearest companions and shows tenderness to his wife.
Waves warmly to mounted soldiers and responds to their greeting with enthusiasm.
Shows decisiveness and confidence in deciding to raise his children personally despite social norms.
Appears calm, confident, and well-prepared, dressed impeccably in uniform and helmet, indicating readiness and professionalism.
Responds warmly and positively to others, demonstrating social competence and confidence in leadership.
Kisses his baby son and wife Nina, holds his child high with a huge grin amidst cheers
Watches the deer he shot die, takes a swig from the flask and toasts 'To death--the best sauce to life!'
Offers Nina a gentle compliment calling her 'rather lovely' after she struggles with her corset.
Watches silently and becomes serious when reminded about being late, showing concern for punctuality.
Remarks about women’s restrictive clothing somewhat teasingly but not mockingly, indicating mild tolerance with a hint of traditional view.
Puts on formal wear in a stiff but bemused manner, watches others preparing, notes the time indicating awareness of schedule.
Makes a dry, slightly teasing comment about appearance but then falls silent instead of engaging more fully with Nina, possibly indicating emotional reserve or hesitation.
Jokes self-deprecatingly about lack of medals in front of Nina, showing vulnerability and humor.
Expresses concern for his son's future and willingness to endure social discomfort for his benefit.
Shows self-awareness about lacking medals and uses humor to deflect potential criticism about his appearance at the ball.
Expresses concern about his career stagnation and the need to secure advancement for his son, indicating strategic thinking and long-term planning.
Acknowledges the importance of appearances and social standing despite personal indifference, demonstrating pragmatic understanding of societal norms.
Nods greetings to fellow officers as he enters the party and acknowledges hellos from random partygoers.
Dances gracefully and sociably with his wife Nina on the dance floor.
Responds to being excluded and laughed at by officers with a lighthearted comment to Nina, showing composure and good humor.
Bows gracefully and courteously gives his wife to another officer to dance, despite being edged out.
Breaks his cigar in two after being shut out and excluded from the officers' gathering, indicating frustration but not open hostility.

Maintains composure and responds calmly to social exclusion by officers during the dance, using dry wit ('I am dancing with you. So I’ve got the better of the bargain.'), showing emotional intelligence and confidence.
He acknowledges the social slight (not being toasted) but does not lose his composure, exhibiting self-control.
Breaks his cigar in two after being excluded (door closed) from officers' conversation, hinting at internal frustration but without direct confrontation or assertive reaction.
Grabs the cane from the officer who is caning a grunt, expressing distaste for the abuse and telling the officer 'We lead the men--we don’t beat them into submission!'
Supervises troops loading heavy artillery shells carefully, shows clear knowledge of limits on load capacity.
Intervenes firmly and appropriately to stop an officer from caning a soldier, promoting leadership by example rather than abuse.
Responds respectfully but somewhat uncertainly when informed of sudden assignment to Royal Geographical Society and possible expedition to North Pole, showing slight surprise.
Politely greets Sir George Goldie and Sir John Scott Keltie, including a handshake and formal address.
Answers questions calmly and respectfully despite underlying tension.
Does not respond to a pointed question about controversial intelligence service; remains silent.
Politely knocks and introduces himself confidently to high-ranking officials, demonstrating social and professional poise.
Answers most questions about his service clearly and succinctly, showing control and awareness of his career.
Remains silent and gives no answer when questioned about the 'yellow document' and intelligence service in Morocco, leading to vague disgust from Goldie.
States his commitment to King and country when questioned, responds respectfully to inquiries about religion and knowledge.
Responds to geopolitical briefing with a polite but somewhat detached comment ('I’m not sure what it has to do with me, Sir').
States that his record speaks for itself and asserts commitment to King and country confidently.
Acknowledges limited knowledge of Bolivia, admitting he only knows what he has read.
Responds respectfully but questions the relevance of the information to himself.
Acknowledges his own survey work was long ago, showing honesty about his current skill status.
Expresses desire for active, challenging posting rather than routine survey work.
Smiles confidently when asked to decide about the dangerous jungle exploration.
Refuses to have his son caned for wearing the wrong frock coat, showing leniency and kindness.
Moves closer to Nina and touches her abdomen after she reveals she is pregnant again, showing affectionate support.
Swears that the thought of his family will be his greatest inspiration to succeed, expressing sincere commitment and love.
Nods in appreciation when Nina gives him a book of poems for his journey, acknowledging her care with warmth.
Gently tells his son to go back to sleep and explains why he must go away, showing concern for his safety.
Sits at the edge of the bed and patiently answers his son's many questions, even laughing gently.
Expresses deep love to his son and acknowledges a heartfelt gift with visible emotion.
Explains dangers clearly to his son and shows emotional strength in a tender family moment before a dangerous journey.
Uses affection and motivation to prepare his son for future challenges with a meaningful gift and encouraging words.
Avoids giving overly complex answers, showing self-awareness of communication limits with a child, but laughs at questions which might indicate slight dismissiveness.
Hugs and kisses his son tightly, smiles through tears.
Protects himself from a pickpocket quickly but without unnecessary aggression; uses verbal warning.
Observes conflict around him calmly, does not intervene in fights or altercations.
Tussles awkwardly and even humorously with Costin instead of reacting with anger or hostility.
Expresses incredulity and upset when Costin delays revealing himself, showing frustration but not outright rejection.
Keeps calm enough to ask Costin who he is instead of immediately commanding or expelling him.
Spots a suspicious man repeatedly, takes initiative to confront him by hiding in a pantry and preparing his weapon.
Effectively immobilizes and controls a potentially threatening man despite an awkward tussle.
Questions the man's delayed introduction in a slightly incredulous and upset manner, showing some emotional reaction but also doubt about the aide's judgement.
Bangs down his knife and commands Costin to show paperwork, calmly assesses the situation without hostility.
Asks Costin about his family, shows awareness of personal stakes.
States that he is willing to sacrifice his family for the mission's success, emphasizing duty over personal attachments.
Takes Costin's whiskey flask to prevent him from drinking, implying care and concern for his potential performance.
Commands Costin to show paperwork, assesses his skill and background calmly and confidently.
Demonstrates clear understanding of the stakes by emphasizing personal sacrifice and reputation for success.
Disarms potential threat by taking away Costin’s whiskey flask to prevent impaired judgment.
Takes whiskey flask from Costin and pours alcohol into sink, warning it has destroyed many a fine man.
Avoids fruit seller’s ad-libbing in train, seems concerned and remote.
Explains change in plan to Costin calmly and practically, showing concern for safety and priority of mission.
Refuses to take whiskey offered by Costin and pours it down the sink, stating it has destroyed many a fine man.
Carefully analyzes new intelligence from a cable and adjusts expedition plans accordingly, prioritizing mapping the Verde River due to political changes.
Displays concern and seriousness about the situation, showing focus and strategic thinking rather than carelessness.
Expresses the necessity to depend on each other to survive the dangerous journey.
Shares a personal poem given by his wife Nina, showing sincerity and emotional openness.
Focuses on the mission urgency and war stakes but remains attentive to his companion’s concerns.
Plans a detailed survey route with careful attention to mapping and timing, showing clear understanding of mission importance.
Acknowledges the long odds honestly but reinforces mutual dependence and survival strategy with Costin.
Momentarily speechless when confronted with the overwhelming odds, indicating a brief hesitation.
Reads a meaningful poem from Nina for inspiration and morale on the difficult journey.
Hacks away with astonishing furor to clear a path and reveal the Amazon, shares the awe quietly with Costin.
Stifles a brief smile and maintains a steely front despite visible excitement.
Shows calm and steady behavior when encountering a snake, easing tension.
Engages Costin in friendly conversation while trekking through difficult jungle conditions.
References a manual recommending keeping only essentials and living off the land, indicating preparedness and knowledge.
Steps over a bright yellow snake with studied calm, showing confidence and control in a dangerous environment.
Stops periodically to check map and surveying equipment, demonstrating good expedition skills and attention to detail.
Breathes heavily but continues hacking through dense jungle, showing persistence and physical capability but possibly struggling with environmental conditions.
Makes a joking comment about killing bugs as obstacles to their path.
Gestures to Costin to keep moving after seeing footprints and silently watching Indians, maintains calm and control.
Shakes head slightly to indicate uncertainty rather than fear or judgment when confronted with evidence of possible cannibals.
Observes footprints and notices Indians silently watching, maintains composure and signals to continue moving cautiously with guns ready.
Looks directly into the eyes of a hostile native and gestures calmly to proceed, showing confidence and control in a tense situation.
Responds to Costin’s question about potential cannibals with a measured, noncommittal gesture indicating uncertainty rather than panic.
Jokes about killing bugs as obstacles and notes some are edible, indicating a light-hearted, practical approach to minor challenges, showing mental resilience and adaptability.
Maintains composure and observes details carefully when entering a difficult environment, noting the harsh conditions and key features around him.
Responds politely and formally when introduced to a young officer, showing social ease in official contexts.
Refuses to accept mission cancellation and insists on continuing despite dangers.
Addresses Corporal Manley repeatedly and directly, seeking support with "Are you WITH me, Corporal?"
Shows concern for practical matters by asking about an Indian guide.
Refuses to accept mission cancellation and commands to proceed despite official orders.
Quickly assesses situation and asks for practical resources (Indian guide).
Appears somewhat dismissive of government authority and logistics, potentially risking support.
Introduces himself and his mission confidently to the Baron, attempting diplomatic engagement despite a lack of immediate response.
Maintains polite conversation and compliments the Baron on his opera house, showing social tact and adaptability.
Persistence despite Baron's silence and indirect replies, showing patience and control.
Insists on employing Tadjui despite the Texan Gunman’s warnings about his rebelliousness and treatment, indicating a willingness to protect or support him.
Promises favorable treatment from his country in place of money, suggesting a trustful and sincere attempt at negotiation.
Maintains composure and listens respectfully during tense negotiation, avoiding embarrassment or confrontation.
Calmly negotiates with the Texan gunman to acquire Tadjui and men despite tense circumstances, showing strategic intent and composure.
Promises highly favorable treatment from his country as a form of negotiation despite lacking immediate tangible resources like money, showing resourcefulness but also some risk.
Is momentarily at a loss for words when Baron De Gondoriz questions his negotiation strategy, indicating a momentary lapse in confidence or preparation.
Responds politely and attempts to maintain dignity during Baron De Gondoriz's provocative statements, indicating social skill and restraint.
Promises to ensure the story of the people they helped will be told if they survive.
Shows patience initially but loses a bit of it when questioned by Costin.
Notices the scars on Tadjuí's back, indicating awareness and recognition of others' suffering.
Takes practical leadership in organizing native workers to build rafts and shares drink between them.
Pockets a letter from his wife without reading it, then focuses on asking for camp location.
Steps near men and helps secure a badly loaded parcel, interrupting their work to improve safety.
Addresses the men firmly about the seriousness of the journey and the discipline required.
Pockets a letter from his wife instead of reading it, showing emotional control and focus.
Asks local guide Tadjui precisely where to pitch camp, relying on local knowledge.
Studies the river and map carefully, attentive to details and surroundings.
Securely adjusts improperly loaded parcel on the raft, taking initiative to fix problems promptly.
Addresses the entire group with clear expectations and commitment to rigorous schedule.
Averts his gaze from hostile onlookers, quietly focuses on his map and mission.
Tightens the rope and rallies his men with a confident declaration to work twelve hours a day and not turn back.
Takes meticulous notes on flora, fauna, temperature, and barometric readings during the expedition.
Averts his gaze when the Texan gunman makes a threatening gesture, possibly avoiding confrontation.
Begins to divide his attention between surveying and admiring the scenery, indicating some distraction.
Half-jokingly invites Manley to play music to ease the silence.
Shares the photo and information about his newborn son with the group.
Acknowledges Costin's suggestion and respectfully accepts it about the photo.
Takes photographs to document and map the region systematically.
Light-heartedly addresses the silence by encouraging music to maintain group morale.
Carefully considers advice from Costin about keeping the photo private and acts on it.
Offers help to Urquhart by stepping onto the raft to pull the fishing net in.
Encourages Costin to get closer to the abandoned ship to seek news or food.
Momentarily bewildered and freezes when confronted with the disturbing sight on the boat.
Accepts Costin's advice and puts the photo away, showing openness to input and trust in his team.
Takes initiative to help Urquhart pull in the fishing net, demonstrating hands-on and cooperative behavior.
Commands Costin to move closer to the abandoned German ship to possibly seek news or supplies, showing strategic thinking and leadership.
Is momentarily bewildered and freezes upon seeing the lone man on the ship, indicating a brief lapse or uncertainty in response to an unexpected situation.
Struggles underwater tangled in a fishing net with the wounded Urquhart, then pulls himself along the rope to safety instead of risking both their lives.
Untangles himself from the rope underwater and escapes piranhas by pulling himself along the rope despite dangerous conditions.
Momentarily bewildered and freezes when the attack begins, showing hesitation under sudden threat.
Helps urgently pull Urquhart aboard the raft despite danger from piranhas and arrows.
Thanks Mr. Costin sincerely for his aid.
Shows anguish at the damage to personal items (letter, family photographs) but collects them carefully.
Remains alert and focused during a difficult and grim situation, helping others quietly.
Pulls himself along the rope through piranha-infested waters under enemy attack.
Leads the effort to pull Urquhart aboard the raft despite dangerous conditions.
Recognizes the death of Urquhart quickly and maintains composure.
Collects and acknowledges the importance of his soaked personal effects despite exhaustion.
Remains alert and focused on mapmaking and progress while the group faces illness and scarcity.
Moves to check on Tadjui and asks if they are close to their destination.
Looks at his men worriedly and voices concern about surviving another attack.
Looks at Tadjui as though he is mad and turns away devastated, under his breath mutters 'Christ...'.
Reaches for his rifle and loads it, preparing for potential danger.
Notices signs of sickness in his companions and himself, tries to gauge survival chances, consults local guide about journey length and dangers.
Dismisses or reacts skeptically to indigenous guide’s optimistic description of a 'city of gold', suggesting potential closed-mindedness or disbelief.
Prepares for potential danger by loading his rifle and pocketing spare shells, showing readiness and caution.
Shows signs of emotional reaction (devastated, muttering 'Christ...') potentially indicating stress or loss of composure.
Speaks quietly and attentively to the shivering Costin, shows concern for his condition.
Prepares for danger by keeping rifle ready and alert; no undue panic shown.
Shares letters with Costin, suggests reading together in a dire situation.
Lets Costin read the letter aloud due to his own emotional difficulty.
Shows deep emotional pain and vulnerability openly, tearing up.
Gently takes the letter back from Costin and burns it, a symbolic and private act.
Shakes his head at the preposterousness of the letter's contents but does not lash out at Costin or others.
Burns the letter from his family after hearing the news, visibly distressed and anguished, questioning his decisions.
Admits to emotional pain and doubts his choice to be in the jungle after hearing about his family’s welfare.
Responds to Dan's plea by insisting he walk and threatens him with a knife at his throat.
Shows concern by calling repeatedly to Mr. Costin who is unresponsive and appears upset.
Checks his chronometer and organizes a rest period for the group at dawn, displaying situational awareness and leadership.
Confronts Dan’s weakness harshly by threatening him with his knife to force him to continue, demonstrating tough decisiveness under pressure.
Despite frailty, maintains mental control while others are incapacitated or despondent, showing psychological resilience and command.
Appears visibly upset and concerned when Mr. Costin is unresponsive, revealing emotional engagement but possibly detracting from calm composure.
Intervenes to stop men from fighting over rotten banana, urging 'Stop it--get--we’re not savages!'
Stands firm in face of mutiny and armed threat from Dan, trying to maintain order
Interrupts a fight over a rotten banana and commands others to stop being savages, attempting to maintain order and discipline in an extremely dire situation.
Faces a mutiny with multiple men ready to charge at him, but steels himself and does not lose composure despite imminent threat.
Fails to anticipate the internal mutiny brewing among his men due to starvation and fear, leading to a chaotic near-violent confrontation.
Gently instructs the group to prepare for a photograph, showing consideration for others amid exhaustion.
Stops Manley from tracking the missing Indian guides, demonstrating trust and deference to their role in the expedition.
Responds to the missing guides with calm and quiet leadership instead of anger or blame.
Slowly takes out surveying equipment and camera to document the source of the river, demonstrating methodical and purposeful behavior.
Orders a group photograph despite the group's exhaustion, displaying leadership and awareness of importance of records.
Stops Manley from hastily tracking footprints, showing restraint and thoughtful decision-making.
Hears subtle noises, signals the group to be quiet, and moves cautiously into the brush, indicating alertness and tactical caution.
Silently takes the shot at the deer to provide food for the group.
Does not respond to Dan's panic or insults, remains composed.
Immediately encourages the group to start a fire and prepare the food after the successful kill.
Freezes when seeing something strange, but does not share fear or hesitation with others; instead, proceeds forward determinedly.
Carefully aims and successfully shoots a difficult, fleeing target (deer) in dense jungle conditions, earning praise from an experienced companion.
Immediately identifies and investigates archaeological clues (statue, paintings, pottery shards) upon encountering them, demonstrating keen observation and decisive action to pursue the mission.
Excitedly shares the discovery with the others, acknowledges indigenous knowledge, energetically involves companions.
Charges forward into risky situations, exposing himself and companions to danger without obvious caution.
Expresses hope for survival and eagerness to share findings with the world, showing a communal and sincere attitude.

Immediately recognizes and validates the presence of significant archaeological artifacts (pottery, rock paintings) and enthusiastically shares this discovery with the others, showing alertness and confidence.
Rummages through the mud to collect pottery fragments despite the mess, showing hands-on determination and dedication to evidence collection.
Challenges Costin's assumption that no one had been there before, demonstrating critical thinking and assertiveness based on his observations.
Fails to notice or anticipate the presence of the black panther that attacks the dog and causes fear among the group, indicating a momentary lapse in situational awareness.
Decides to follow the watershed and pragmatically prays it will lead them out, reflecting adaptive problem-solving under pressure.
Approaches official despite filthy, disheveled appearance; requests help and contact with family sincerely.
Makes intense, possibly unsettling request about war and willingness to fight.
Devastated and apologetic for early arrival and hardship of party
Politely refuses a chair despite frail condition
Responds with inclusive kindness—'Yes. For ALL of us.' when offered food and rest
Completes all maps and achieves great discoveries ahead of schedule despite difficult conditions.
Mistakes the year and believes he arrived late when he is actually early.
Maintains composure and dignity despite appearing frail and devastated.
Does not initially notice the calendar date discrepancy leading to confusion about timing.
Greets wife and children warmly amidst a bustling crowd, openly expresses emotion and admiration to his wife.
Leads an expedition that conquers Hell Verde (a difficult objective) and returns to a hero's welcome.
Collapses suddenly after announcing the conquest, showing possible physical or mental strain.
Handles intense crowd pressure and searches for family amid chaos with determination and focus.
Shows emotional vulnerability and tears at reunion, indicating human warmth but not directly linked to competence.
Hugs his son Jack tightly and bursts into tears, demonstrating emotional openness and sincere affection despite Jack's lack of response.
Registers awkwardness and disappointment when his son's affection is absent, indicating sensitivity and vulnerability.
Responds warmly and emotionally to his son Jack, hugging him tightly and showing vulnerability through tears.
Recognizes and registers Jack's lack of reaction and interest, noting the awkwardness and his own fading smile.
Receives a warm and enthusiastic reception at the Royal Geographical Society event, being greeted as the toast of the town and moved away by an influential figure for introduction to the host.
Responds politely to James Murray's compliments with modest greetings and returns praise sincerely.
Shows sympathy toward the natives by acknowledging they deserve compassion.
Is warmly received and honored by senior members of the Royal Geographical Society, indicating recognition of his skills and achievements.
Engages respectfully and knowledgeably in conversation about exploration and scientific issues, demonstrating confidence and intelligence.
Expresses empathy for natives and acknowledges the vast unexplored areas, showing thoughtful and informed perspective.
Does not display any hesitation or uncertainty in the social setting, acting with assuredness.
Responds confidently and intellectually to Sir John Scott Keltie's subtle challenge about his mental fitness after an arduous trip, asserting his mind is perfectly fit and open.
Steps away from a prominent figure and observes others socializing, indicating self-awareness and composure in a social/academic setting.
Displays reasonable authority and discipline with his children by setting clear boundaries about handling artifacts, signaling responsible behavior and situational control.
Engages less in social laughter or light conversation, perhaps missing social cues or humor, which might indicate slight social rigidity or lack of flexibility.
Refuses to donate his findings to RGS out of distrust and a desire to prove his case; admits the society undervalues his discoveries.
Acknowledges Nina as the true cause of others' envy, showing appreciation and warmth toward her.
Expresses regret for not engaging the local Indians more directly, recognizing their value and what he could have learned from them.
Refuses to donate important archeological evidence to the RGS because he feels they do not respect or understand the significance of his discoveries.
Acknowledges his own failure to engage directly with indigenous people to learn from them, showing self-reflection and insight.
Spends time researching in the archives and carefully examining ancient documents alongside Nina, demonstrating diligent and focused scholarship.
Engages Nina with a light, teasing 'Cheeky?' to gain her attention.
Expresses courteous respect to Sir George Goldie with a sincere reply 'Yes, Sir George. I shall try.'
Shows no explicit warmth toward Nina's silence or emotional state when she ignores him initially.
Engages with the audience at the Royal Geographical Society and interacts confidently with notable figures such as Sir George Goldie.
Fails to acknowledge the potential value of engaging more directly with the indigenous people, admitting he should have done so.
Responds calmly and firmly to skepticism and interruption during a rowdy meeting, defending his beliefs without personal attack.
Acknowledges and addresses Mr. Barclay politely despite the latter's mocking tone.
Challenges misconceptions about destruction of Amazonia, showing concern for the environment.
Stands poised and accepts applause with modesty, not boasting.
Delivers a confident and well-received speech proposing a controversial theory about a hidden civilization in Amazonia.
Responds calmly and assertively to skepticism and interruptions during his presentation.
Faces skepticism and ridicule (e.g., being called the 'resident Buddhist') but maintains composure and conviction.
Acknowledges historical bigotry and calls for engagement with and understanding of an indigenous civilization
Passionately defends his evidence despite ridicule, appealing for learning and respect
Shouts to assert his point over boos and laughter
Presents firsthand evidence and argues passionately for the existence of an ancient civilization despite skepticism and ridicule.
Insists on the validity of his discoveries and challenges prevailing prejudices, showing intellectual bravery and confidence.
Fails to sway a hostile scientific audience and is met with mockery, indicating a possible lack of effective persuasion or communication skills.
Yells above the crowd to share exciting news about the lost city, engaging others enthusiastically.
Beams and points encouragingly at James Murray after his enthusiastic challenge.
Looks around the room catching the attention of others, encouraging participation.
Confidently presents historically significant evidence about a lost city, inspiring others with his intelligent argument and vision.
Energizes and leads a group to accept the challenge of exploring the jungle despite its known dangers, showing leadership and decisiveness.
Touches hands tenderly with Nina after intimacy, expresses hope and admiration for James Murray's contribution.
Is surprised and somewhat amused by Nina's desire to join the next expedition, laughs nervously.
Initially resists Nina accompanying him on the expedition, citing physical rigors and seeming protective.
Delivers a determined speech at the podium, showing confidence and command.
Acknowledges the importance of James Murray's participation, showing recognition of expertise and strategic thinking.
Is surprised and flummoxed by Nina's readiness to accompany him, showing some lack of anticipation or underestimation of others' abilities.
Voices doubt about a woman's ability to survive the rigors of the journey, reflecting biased or limited perspective rather than objective evaluation of capability.
Expresses love and concern for his wife, acknowledging the danger he faces; kneels when speaking to her.
Refuses to approach or comfort his wife as she expresses her feelings, standing apart and not physically comforting her.
Dismisses his wife's feelings and aspirations, appeals to traditional gender roles, and ignores her desires for partnership and shared experience.
Refuses to take his wife into the jungle due to concern over danger, prioritizing safety.
Expresses traditional gender role views, unwilling to consider his wife's aspirations.
Notices Costin's maggot infection and pauses, shows concern.
Makes a joking comment to Costin about insect bites to lighten the mood.
Checks on James Murray and encourages him to stay well-equipped despite his burdens.
Insists Murray keep one change of clothes and his mattress for safety and preparedness.
Defends Murray against Costin's dismissive and negative remarks about Murray's abilities.
Keeps calm and does not immediately draw his rifle when attacked, unlike others.
Insists that Murray keep one change of clothes and mattress to avoid being slowed down, showing practical judgment and leadership.
Rebukes Costin for underestimating Murray’s valor and potential, indicating confidence in his team's abilities and keen assessment.
Calmly observes the attack and scans the environment instead of immediately firing, displaying situational awareness and restraint.
Commands his men to hold their fire to avoid unnecessary violence.
Attempts peaceful communication by waving a handkerchief and calling out 'Friend' repeatedly, despite danger.
Encourages singing of a patriotic song amidst a hostile situation to boost morale.
Holds surveying book in front of his face to protect himself from arrows, calmly endures attack without retaliation.
Kneels humbly on the raft as the Guarayo Indian takes his handkerchief and helps him across, showing respect and trust.
Braves a dangerous situation by standing with arrows flying at him, uses a surveying book to shield himself, and remains calm when arrows hit the book.
After the attack stops, he closes his eyes and waits silently, showing composure and restraint rather than panic.
Kneels humbly on a flimsy raft to be taken across by a local Guarayo Indian, showing diplomatic behavior and trust in local knowledge.
Sympathizes with James Murray's reluctance, tries to calm the group, and asks them to trust his experience about engaging the tribe.
Insists on engaging with a cannibalistic tribe despite the group's fear, putting them at risk.
Acknowledges the others' fear but maintains a calm and understanding attitude toward their concerns.
Does not directly address the fear or concerns when the group agrees with Murray, instead shows a brief look of madness and walks away.
Emerges calmly and confidently after apparent danger, waves to his men, displaying control of the situation.
Recognizes and interprets the chief's language to assert safety despite visible threats, showing knowledge and confidence in judgment.
Attempts to persuade his fearful companions to trust his experience and engage with potentially hostile natives, demonstrating leadership and decisiveness.
Dismisses others’ fears and insists on interaction with cannibal tribe based on cultural understanding, risking group safety.
Does not respond verbally when others begin to retreat and doubt him, showing momentary loss of control or failure to reassure his group.
Gives a glittering necklace as a gift to the Guarayos and speaks warmly about having sons, attempting to build a friendly rapport.
Acknowledges cultural differences with a momentary loss of smile, showing some tension but still remains engaged.
Bows his head in thanks as he takes the fish after the Guarayo boy catches it for him
Engages respectfully with the Guarayo people, communicates through subtitles with appreciation (e.g. saying 'Food--yes--thank you!')
Acknowledges the Guarayo's advanced methods of farming, indicating respect rather than dismissiveness
Communicates effectively with the Guarayo, interprets their signs and words, and understands they may find more help further down the river.
Shows cultural sensitivity by adopting native face paint and bowing in thanks after receiving the fish.
Exhibits patience and observation rather than reckless action while discovering the large indigenous population with advanced farming methods.
Acknowledges the communal, egalitarian nature of the families they observe and finds it humbling.
Calmly reassures others about the missing Mr. Murray, affirming his capabilities without panic.
Teaches the Guarayos leader to handshake as a goodbye gesture, showing respect and friendliness.
Responds to the Guarayos chief’s offer to stay with them with sincere gratitude but explains his mission must continue.
Offers to look after James Murray after finding him lost.
Displays visible anger and rage upon discovering the empty caramel box from his family was taken, showing personal hurt and betrayal.
Scolds James Murray harshly for stealing and violating trust, comparing Murray unfavorably to his sons and expressing frustration.
Assesses Murray's injury and warns of danger, emphasizing consequences of not trusting the group and 'so-called savage'
Walks away after warning without further comforting Murray
Commands Murray to swim to shore during dangerous rafting incident, showing urgency and concern for safety
Becomes enraged and insults Murray calling him 'pink-eyed weakling' after Murray threatens to capsize raft
Assesses Murray's wound accurately and warns about risk of blood poisoning, showing medical knowledge and situational awareness.
Advises that staying with the group and trusting the local 'savage' would have ensured safety and care, demonstrating good judgment about survival strategy.
Maneuvers the raft skillfully on a rough river, showing physical and navigational competence.
Commands Murray decisively to swim to shore to avoid danger, showing leadership and quick decision-making.
Gets enraged and insults Murray ('pink-eyed weakling'), potentially showing a lack of emotional control under stress.
Loss of two crates of supplies after raft tips over while trying to control the situation, indicating some failure to manage the immediate crisis effectively.
Glares at Murray with contempt after losing supplies, refuses to show mercy or slow down despite Murray's condition.
Ignores Murray's pleas and suffering, focusing solely on progress and schedule.
Directs the group firmly to pitch camp for the night, showing practical leadership though without evident empathy.
Directs the raft to shore skillfully using a bamboo pole.
Focuses on assessing their current location and schedule by questioning Costin, showing situational awareness.
Orders to pitch camp at abandoned huts to rest and evaluate progress, demonstrating planning and practical leadership.
Shows contempt and a harsh attitude toward Murray’s plea for compassion, ignoring a sick man’s needs.
Dismisses Murray’s suffering and emotional appeals, indicating possible rigidity and lack of interpersonal sensitivity.
Refers to James Murray as a 'cancer' and suggests removing him to ensure group survival.
Insists the sick Murray cannot slow the group down, emphasizing group survival over individual suffering.
Rebukes violent intentions toward Murray and intervenes to disarm Costin, preventing harm.
Acknowledges the difficult choices but insists he will not abandon Murray and mentions nearby mining camps as possible help.
Offers last horse, supplies, and a guide to James Murray instead of leaving him to die.
Acknowledges the slim chance of survival for Murray but still does the best he can to help.
Calmly sends Murray away despite tension and Murray’s rage.
Insists on continuing the expedition despite the dire circumstances, showing determination but possibly disregarding others' safety.
Expresses deep rage and frustration physically by bashing a rock, indicating emotional stress but not directed at others.
Writes a message instructing British officials to withhold contacting family unless definitive news is available, showing consideration and protection for others' feelings.
Speaks kindly to his toddler daughter, establishing an immediate warm connection.
Allows his sons to finish their rugby game without interruption, showing respect for their play.
Responds curtly and focused to the English officer about sending a telegram, without friendliness or warmth.
Turns back for the good of the men, fighting tears, shows emotional vulnerability.
Plans to tell his boys honestly what has happened after their game.
Looks lost and withdrawn at the Royal Geographical Society, buries his head in his hands.
Eyes James Murray without any hint of animosity despite past conflicts.
Turns back from expedition for the good of the men, acknowledges failure with emotional honesty.
Feels humiliated and states 'I accomplished nothing' despite efforts.
Walks into Royal Geographical Society looking lost and tense, indicating possible uncertainty or lack of confidence in professional setting.
Calmly congratulates Murray on his safe return with a trace of a smile.
Firmly denies abandoning Murray and explains decisions made to save lives.
Dismisses Murray's accusations and defends his team's efforts passionately.
Invites others to verify his claims, standing up for himself openly.
Engages in a confrontational exchange with Murray, leading to insults and tension.
Expresses willingness to reconcile for the general good despite personal conflict.
Reminds others of how he saved an opponent's life against his own men's urging.
Avoids a direct apology and instead focuses on justifying his past behavior.
Willing to reconcile for the general good despite personal conflict, and requests to hear conditions before agreeing.
Responds calmly and with a reminder of his own past aid despite provocation, showing control and reasoned defense.
Apologizes sincerely to his crew for misjudging a man’s character and admits a mistake.
Resigns from the institution after conflict and refuses to further embarrass others, showing respect despite disagreement.
Shows gentle concern for his wife Nina, reassuring her not to worry about the war.
Acknowledges a mistake in judgment, apologizes to his crew for misjudging their leader, and resolves to no longer make that error.
Decides to resign from the institution and proceed independently after conflicts, showing a confident assertion of autonomy.
Responds to his wife's concern about the war with calmness and confidence, citing his life experience and preparedness.
Responds to family’s emotional appeals with composed but firm answers about duty; acknowledges military obligation despite personal cost.
Shows visible shock and anger when confronted by his wife about his priorities and family obligations.
Lunges across the room and slaps his son with tremendous and frightening ferocity during a family argument.
Steps back after the outburst, showing some control despite anger.
Shares a laugh with Manley and jokes about Mr. Murray's failed expedition.
Speaks to Arthur Manley firmly but shows concern for the troops by ordering cooks and signallers to also prepare for the attack; urges men to write to loved ones if they haven't.
Dismisses plans to withdraw, insisting on fighting to the death despite the possibility of being overwhelmed.
Identifies enemy movement using periscope and correctly assesses impending attack.
Decides to prepare for a dawn assault despite risks and limited troops, showing decisiveness and confidence.
Rejects withdrawal plans as absurd and insists on fighting to the end, showing strong leadership and resolve under pressure.
Encourages soldiers to write to loved ones before the attack, demonstrating consideration and emotional intelligence.
Appears visibly unsettled by situation but still acts decisively and gives orders.
Welcomes the mystic to bless the troops and expresses sincere respect for spiritual aid before battle.
Introduces his men proudly and inclusively to the mystic, sharing camaraderie.
Engages respectfully with the mystic and accepts spiritual support to prepare for battle, demonstrating open-mindedness and leadership in fostering morale among troops.
Allows himself to be hypnotized by the mystic without apparent skepticism or critical evaluation, potentially indicating a susceptibility to unscientific influence.
Expresses a heartfelt vision of finding a lost city with his family, showing longing and sincerity.
Sits quietly by himself after hearing about his destiny and the cruelties of the world.
Clearly visualizes and articulates the goal of finding a lost city in the jungle, including imagining his family accompanying him there.
Expresses a strong, almost mystical conviction about his quest and destiny despite the ambiguity and danger, showing confidence in his purpose.
Notices a terrified private and gives an impassioned speech emphasizing humanity, mutual esteem, and fighting for each other rather than rank or ambition.
Includes humor and camaraderie with men, sharing a laugh even in tense moments.
Covers his head from falling debris during a shell explosion, showing situational awareness and self-preservation.
Patrols the trench despite exhaustion and danger, demonstrating responsibility and leadership.
Gives an inspiring and thoughtful speech to rally frightened soldiers, showing emotional intelligence and command presence.
Laughs with the men after his speech, building camaraderie.
No indications of panic or loss of control during chaos and bombardment.
Takes a small drawing of Amazonia Jungle and holds it to his head almost like praying before battle.
Leads men into a deadly charge, inflicting very high casualties with no evident hesitation.
Blows the whistle to lead a charge, demonstrates leadership and calm under intense battle conditions.
Takes a small drawing of the Amazonia jungle to his head almost like praying, showing focus and emotional poise before battle.
Emerges from trench amid extreme danger, observes the losses around him including a comrade's death, and continues to move forward, showing resilience and situational awareness.
Whips off gas mask and starts to yell possibly disregarding safety protocols in a gas attack scenario.
Urgently encourages fellow soldiers and explorers to keep moving forward in both battlefield and jungle.
Stands in the middle of a deadly battlefield seemingly detached and absorbed in his own state, showing little apparent interaction or concern for others in immediate danger.
Kisses his children and strokes his son's head tenderly upon awakening, showing affection and care.
Asks about the fate of his men and comrades, showing concern for others beyond himself.
Shows concern and inquiries about the wellbeing of his comrades (asks about Costin and the rest of the men) despite his own injuries.
Remains focused on important details (his military role and consequences) even while confused and weakened due to injury.
Shows emotional tenderness and connection towards his family despite his physical and mental stress (kissing children, stroking child's head).
Appears disoriented and confused about his own condition and situation (asks 'What’s… happened to me?').
Comforts his son Jack by touching his face and tear despite difficulty in making eye contact.
Dismisses the term 'civilized' as an obscenity and defends the 'so-called savages' of the jungle for their humanity.
Turns away quietly disappointed upon hearing he may never return to Amazonia, not seeking further comfort or expressing bitterness openly.
Expresses disappointment quietly and turns away when told he may never return to the jungle, showing emotional control but some resignation.
Critiques the term 'civilized' with moral conviction and insight reflecting his experience and strong values.
Reaches out gently to his son, showing emotional intelligence and awareness in a difficult moment.
Expresses gratitude for public interest and emphasizes family needs above all.
Pets the family dog while seated with family, showing affection and comfort.
Expresses hope that new explorers will not destroy what they discover, showing respect and care for the environment and culture.
Receives news of new explorations with modern technology and weapons, responds thoughtfully expressing concern for preservation rather than destruction.
Shows attentiveness and engagement by immediately reacting to the news of new voyages and studying the map of South America.
Does not display any outward sign of frustration or confusion when asked how the reporter found them, maintaining composure.
Compliments his son's rifle skills and offers to retrieve the rabbit himself.
Pondering silently while watching his son, indicating thoughtful concern rather than immediate emotional expression.
Engages in quiet, supportive conversation with his son about post-war difficulties and acknowledges his son's writings positively.
Acknowledges and encourages his son's growing skill with the rifle, showing confidence and mentorship.
Insists on retrieving the rabbit himself instead of delegating, demonstrating hands-on involvement and responsibility.
Prepares the rabbit for eating calmly and practically while overseeing the situation, showing practical survival skills and composure.
Engages in reflective conversation about past difficulties and maintains a poised demeanor.
Gives Jack an Indian necklace as a gift, calling it his.
Smiles broadly and beams at his son's enthusiasm.
Expresses being touched by his son's faith in him.
Takes a serious, almost emotional pause, showing vulnerability admitting war took a toll.
Suggests consulting Jack’s mother before agreeing to an expedition, showing respect for family input.
Gives a meaningful gift (Indian necklace) to his son, showing thoughtfulness and cultural connection.
Admits doubt about his own ability to return to the expedition after the war, showing self-awareness but also hesitation.
Shows emotional vulnerability and acknowledges toll of war, indicating realistic self-appraisal but possible decline in physical or mental capacity.
Expresses willingness to consider a new expedition with his son, indicating openness and persistent belief in his goals.
Defers decision to consult with the mother, showing respect for family but also perhaps reluctance or indecisiveness.
Comforts and forgives his son Jack, acknowledging his intentions and offering encouragement.
Encourages and supports Jack's adventurous plans, while realistically cautioning about money and training needed.
Comforts and encourages his son Jack after a difficult conversation, recognizing Jack's good intentions despite prior conflict.
Acknowledges that the upcoming journeys require significant preparation, including money and training.
Remains silent, contemplative before the conversation with his family, possibly indicating thoughtful deliberation.
Expresses confidence in Jack's character and potential despite concerns.
Shows understanding and concern toward Nina's unspoken worries.
Treats Henry Costin's notebooks with great care and respect.
Confidently commits to the expedition and shows faith in team members' character over experience.
Carefully handles important notebooks and prepares maps before the journey.
Expresses surprise at quick acceptance but proceeds decisively.
Leans forward and whispers to persuade Costin to join expedition, emphasizing the importance of the mission and appealing to personal dedication and history.
Acknowledges his own concerns about his family while confidently arguing his son’s qualities to counter objections.
Maintains composure and stops Costin’s protest to clearly state his resolve and belief in his mission, showing leadership and confidence.
Appears surprised when Costin refuses, which could indicate a slight underestimation of others’ resolve or a blind spot.
Wishes others godspeed and the greatest success despite refusal.
Acknowledges and appreciates support from both American newspapers and British societies.
Introduces his son proudly to the press, praising his qualities.
Dismisses other explorers' efforts with indifference and does not acknowledge their merits.
Conducts a confident press conference outlining a demanding, disciplined expedition plan without seeking excessive publicity.
Secures significant funding from a consortium of American newspapers and John D. Rockefeller Jr., demonstrating strong networking and resource acquisition skills.
Dismisses offers of help from the Royal Geographical Society and concerns about competitors' advanced technology, focusing on his own plans.
Accepts well-deserved recognition and highest honor from Royal Geographical Society with grace and confidence.
Displays calm confidence by giving his compass to Keltie as a meaningful token, illustrating assuredness in his mission.
Acknowledges past differences with dignified humility rather than defensiveness.
Grabs both arms of Jack and squeezes, sharing a warm moment before departure.
Reassures Nina not to look for him if he does not return, expressing hope that one of them will survive, conveying sincerity and care.
Acknowledges Brian’s new responsibility with respect and encouragement.
Gives Brian a sealed letter before departure, indicating thoughtfulness and trust.
Ends with awkward silence and somewhat clipped communication after saying arrangements are done.
Carefully arranges to keep copies of important coordinates in multiple secure locations, indicating thorough preparation.
Plans to send dispatches to newspapers, showing confidence and intention to communicate progress.
Shows emotional support and imparts a sense of responsibility to his son, demonstrating leadership and awareness of family dynamics even amid danger.
Expresses acceptance of possible death but encourages resilience and hope, showing mental preparation but possibly underestimating the risks.
Kisses Joan and Nina before leaving, writes a heartfelt poem to his son encouraging bravery and kindness.
Boards the truck unsentimentally without prolonged goodbyes.
Writes a thoughtful poem to his son urging bravery and kindness before embarking on an expedition.
Unsensimentally leaves family behind to pursue a dangerous mission without overt expressions of doubt or fear.
Remains seated and studies a map intently while others engage with the surroundings.
Waves back to crowds enthusiastically demonstrating confidence and awareness of public perception.
Loses his Stetson hat to the wind during travel.
Reassures Jack about his broken compass and asks sincerely how he is faring.
Expresses disappointment at the ruined opera house but tries to maintain a positive outlook.
Thanks the Peon warmly, praises his work, and entrusts him with a final dispatch.
Shakes hands with the Peons and says goodbye before they leave.
Calmly accepts the sight of the dead white men floating in the river.
Takes pictures of the Bakairi Indians, poses with them respectfully.
Engages with the indigenous people to learn about their culture and territory.
Focused on expedition goals, appears determined and serious in approach.
Urgently tries to motivate and protect his son Jack during a life-threatening attack, grabbing him and urging him to keep moving.
Ducks and bolts through the trees at high speed, evading flying wooden clubs and arrows very close to him.
Keeps his son moving and tries to maintain focus despite disorienting conditions and imminent danger.
Gives a flashlight to a Kayapo Indian who appears thrilled with it.
Raises his hands calmly when surrounded by Indians, signaling no aggression.
Whispers to his son reassuringly that they are in no real danger.
Successfully dodges a spear attack and remains calm under intense threat, recognizes signs indicating no real danger despite tense situation.
Raises hands to show peaceful intent when surrounded by potentially hostile Indians, demonstrating situational awareness and conflict de-escalation.
Whispers to his son reassuringly based on prior experience, showing knowledge and confidence in handling dangerous encounters.
Cups his son's chin gently, offers calm reassurance through a spiritual reflection despite danger.
Encourages his son to sit down to show trust to the Kayapo.
Tempering his son's enthusiasm with a firm but gentle correction.
Calms his son and reassures him with thoughtful words about trust and the mystery of life.
Demonstrates knowledge of their situation and responds confidently to his son's concerns about their location.
Encourages his son to sit down to show trust to the Kayapo, demonstrating situational awareness and social tact.
Refuses to prematurely conclude they have reached their goal despite his son's enthusiasm, showing disciplined judgment.
Breaks down crying and expresses deep emotion to his son about their journey together.
Tenderly grabs Jack’s neck in a display of affection.
Gives Jack a letter from his mother meant to give him strength.
Takes measured steps to observe the causeway and does not immediately jump to conclusions despite excitement.
Shows emotional vulnerability and breaks down crying upon realization of achievement.
Pulls out a chair for Nina and the baby at a family gathering.
Stares silently at his son and seems lost in thought after receiving a letter from Nina.
Stares thoughtfully and shows emotional depth when seeing his son at peace; reacts quietly to the letter from Nina, indicating reflective intelligence and emotional awareness.
Lightheartedly jokes with Nina when she wants to read a message first, demonstrating social confidence and ease.
No direct action demonstrating practical skill or decision-making in this excerpt; mostly internal or relational behaviors.
Smiles and kisses his wife’s hand after hearing her heartfelt letter, then gently reaches out to touch his baby's hand.
Smiles warmly, shows affection and tenderness toward his wife and son despite the somber context.
Mentally affirms and accepts his son’s importance and symbolic meaning, demonstrating emotional intelligence and focus.
Behaves passively as natives dance and hold him aloft somewhat sloppily, does not assert control or direct the situation.

Lives among the Indians with Jack, showing trust and cooperation with native people.
